UnitDefinition.Name: Benchmark response type
UnitDefinition.Description: Accepted benchmark response types. Controlled terminology.

Unit.Name: Fraction change
Unit.Description: The benchmark response is defined as a fraction change of the background response (i.e., defined for both increase and decrease). E.g., for a factor of 0.1, the benchmark response is at +/- 10% of background response.

Unit.Name: Percentage change
Unit.Description: The benchmark response is defined as a percentage change of the background response (i.e., defined for both increase and decrease). E.g., for a percentage of 10, the benchmark response is at +/- 10% of background response.

Unit.Name: Fraction of background response
Unit.Description: The benchmark response is defined as a fraction of the background response. E.g., for a factor of 0.9, the benchmark response is at 0.9 times the background response (i.e., a decrease).

Unit.Name: Percentage of background response
Unit.Description: The benchmark response is defined as a percentage of the background response. E.g., for a percentage of 90, the benchmark response is at 90% of the background response (i.e., a decrease).

Unit.Name: Extra risk
Unit.Description: For quantal response types. The benchmark dose is defined as the dose that corresponding with an extra risk of a factor times the background risk. A factor of 0.05 corresponds with 5% extra risk.

Unit.Name: Additional risk
Unit.Description: For quantal response types. The benchmark dose is defined as the dose that corresponding with an additional risk of a factor times the background risk. A factor of 0.05 corresponds with 5% additional risk.

Unit.Name: ED50
Unit.Description: For quantal response types. The benchmark dose is defined as the dose that corresponds with an estimated risk of 50% (ED50).

Unit.Name: Absolute threshold value
Unit.Description: The benchmark dose is defined as an absolute threshold value.

Unit.Name: Absolute difference
Unit.Description: The benchmark dose is defined an absolute difference with the background risk.
